children.name: secret
children.definition: /ˈsiːkrɪt, ˈsiːkrət/  if something is secret, not many people know about it, and they agree not to tell anyone else about it:bí mật
examples: ▪ The letter was written in a secret code.
▪ Secret documents containing details of Britain’s defence plans have been stolen.
▪ The president’s schedule is secret, but there is speculation that he will visit UN troops in the area.
remain/stay secret giữ bí mật
▪ I hope you see how vital it is that our conversation remains secret.
top secret bí mật hàng đầu
when an official document, piece of information etc is very secret
▪ The experiments were top secret.
secret ballot bỏ phiếu kín
a secret vote một cuộc bỏ phiếu bí mật
▪ The Leader of the House will be selected by secret ballot.

children.name: confidential
children.definition: /ˌkɒnfɪˈdenʃəl◂, ˌkɒnfəˈdenʃəl◂ǁˌkɑːn-/  confidential information is known only by a few official people, and must not be told to anyone else, for example because it contains military secrets or private details about people:bí mật
examples: ▪ We hold confidential records on each employee.
▪ Always protect confidential files by locking them with a password.
▪ An employee secretly gave confidential memos to the press.
highly confidential mức độ tuyệt mật cao
very confidentil rất tự tin
▪ The information we received is of a highly confidential nature and relates to national security.

children.name: classified
children.definition: /ˈklæsɪfaɪd, ˈklæsəfaɪd/  classified information or documents are ones that the government has ordered to be kept secret:phân loại
examples: ▪ There is evidence that Huang had access to classified information.
▪ Only licensed companies are eligible to receive, store, or send classified material.

children.name: sensitive
children.definition: /ˈsensɪtɪv, ˈsensətɪv/  information or documents that are sensitive are likely to cause problems or embarrassment if they are made public and therefore they are kept secret:nhạy cảm
examples: ▪ A teenager used his personal computer to break into sensitive US Air Force files.
▪ Your competitors may have access to the company intranet, so never discuss commercially sensitive issues on-line.
highly sensitive : rất nhạy cảm
▪ The minister admitted that highly sensitive documents had been leaked to the press.

children.name: covert
children.definition: /ˈkʌvəʳtˌ ˈkəʊvɜːʳt/  done secretly, especially by a government or official organization, often involving breaking the law:bí mật
examples: ▪ The chief investigator resigned, amid allegations of covert and probably illegal operations.
▪ The abuse of residents in the home was confirmed by covert video surveillance.
covertly[adverb]một cách bí mật
▪ We’re able to operate covertly to monitor the situation.

children.name: undercover
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈkʌvəʳ◂/  working secretly - use this about the activities of the police, the army etc:bí mật, ngầm
examples: ▪ Six members of a drug-smuggling gang were arrested after an 18-month undercover police operation.
▪ The unit is equipped to deal with a variety of situations, including undercover surveillance.
undercover[adverb]bí mật
work/go undercover: làm việc bí mật
▪ Griffiths plays a New York police officer who goes undercover to investigate the murder of a young Jewish man.

children.name: be veiled in secrecy
children.definition: /shrouded in secrecy/cloaked in secrecy/biː ˌveɪld ɪn ˈsiːkrəsi, ˌʃraʊdd ɪn ˈsiːkrəsi, ˌkləʊkt ɪn ˈsiːkrəsi/  if something is veiled, cloaked, or shrouded in secrecy, very little is known about it and it seems very mysterious:được che dấu trong bí mật
examples: ▪ In Japan, the private lives of the Emperor and his family were once veiled in secrecy.
▪ The President’s exact itinerary was cloaked in secrecy for security reasons.
▪ This ground-breaking work is shrouded in secrecy on the instruction of the company’s lawyers.

children.name: hush-hush
children.definition: /ˌhʌʃ ˈhʌʃ◂ǁˈhʌʃ hʌʃ/  informal kept officially secret:chính thức giữ bí mật
examples: ▪ His death was really hush-hush. It was so covered up that you wondered if it wasn’t a suicide.
▪ ‘The Manhattan Project’ was the insiders’ name for the hush-hush project

children.name: cloak-and-dagger
children.definition: /ˌkləʊk ən ˈdægəʳ/  use this about methods and activities that involve a lot of secrecy, especially when this seems unnecessary:nhiều hoạt động bí mật
examples: ▪ He was arrested after a cloak-and-dagger operation involving the CIA and MI6.

children.name: to deliberately not tell sb a secret
not tell anyone
children.definition: /nɒt tel ˈeniwʌn/
examples: ▪ I’m leaving next month to start another job, but don’t tell anyone just yet.
▪ She knew she had cancer, but she didn’t tell anyone.

children.name: keep sth (a) secret
children.definition: keep something (a) secret/ˌkiːp something (ə) ˈsiːkrt/  to not tell other people about something or not let them find out about it:
examples: ▪ He said it was vital to keep Operation Beehive secret.
▪ It was impossible for the affair to be kept secret.
keep sth (a) secret from
▪ At first I tried to keep my illness a secret from my wife.

children.name: not breathe a word
children.definition: /not tell a soul/nɒt ˌbriːð ə ˈwɜːʳd, nɒt ˌtel ə ˈsəʊl/  to not tell anyone anything at all about something, because it is very important that no one knows about it:
examples: ▪ It’s supposed to be a big surprise, so don’t breathe a word.
▪ Don’t worry, I won’t tell a soul about any of this.

children.name: keep quiet
children.definition: /ˌkiːp ˈkwaɪət/  to not tell anyone about something that you know is happening, especially something that other people would disapprove of because it is slightly illegal or unfair:
examples: keep quiet about
▪ I wish I’d kept quiet about the money.
▪ We’d better keep quiet about this for now.
keep it quiet
▪ We can give you a 10% raise, but not the others -- so keep it quiet, won’t you?

children.name: keep something to yourself
children.definition: /ˌkiːp something tə jɔːʳˈself/  to not tell other people something that someone has told you, or something that you have found out about:
examples: ▪ Don’t tell Sam -- he’s incapable of keeping anything to himself.
▪ Branson knew who the killer was, but had kept it to himself for twenty years.

children.name: keep something from
children.definition: /ˈkiːp something frɒm somebody/  to deliberately not tell someone something that you know, especially because you are worried about telling them, or because it might upset them:
examples: ▪ If a patient is dying, I don’t think doctors have a right to keep it from them.
▪ I’ve tried to ask her what’s worrying her, but she says it’s nothing. I’m sure she’s keeping something from me.

children.name: keep back
children.definition: /ˌkiːp ˈbæk/  to not tell someone certain facts about something when telling them everything else about it:
examples: keep something back
▪ I got the feeling he was keeping something back.
keep back something
▪ Although most of the facts were published the government kept back certain details that might prove embarrassing.
keep something back from somebody/keep back something from somebody
▪ I must now confess something which I kept back from you earlier.

children.name: secret
children.definition: /ˈsiːkrɪt, ˈsiːkrət/  something that you do not want other people to know about:bí mật
examples: ▪ I’m not supposed to be telling you this, it’s a secret.
▪ Only Jasper knew my secret.
tell somebody a secret Nói với ai đó một bí mật
▪ Come over here, Luke wants to tell you a secret.
remain/stay a secretGiữ /giữ bí mật
▪ We lived in a small village and I knew that the news wouldn’t remain a secret for very long.
trade secret : bí mật thương mại
information that a company keeps secret from other companies
▪ The task force will concentrate on stopping the theft of trade secrets.
state secretBí mật nhà nước
information that a government keeps secret
▪ A scientist has been arrested for revealing state secrets concerning chemical weapons.
family secretBí mật gia đình
one that only some members of a family know about thành viên trong gia đình
▪ It’s one of those family secrets that we don’t talk about much. Đó là một trong những bí mật gia đình mà chúng ta không nói nhiều.
a closely-guarded/well kept secretmột bí mật được bảo vệ cẩn thận / giữ gìn cẩn thận
one that is kept very secret Một cái được giữ bí mật
▪ His whereabouts are a closely-guarded secret.Nơi ở của ông là một bí mật chặt chẽ.
the secret is out/the secret comes outbí mật là ra / bí mật đi ra
when people get to know something that was being kept secretKhi mọi người biết đến cái gì đó đang được giữ bí mật
▪ Yes, the secret’s out I’m afraid. I’m to be a grandmother.Vâng, bí mật của tôi sợ. Tôi là một bà ngoại.

children.name: skeleton in your cupboard
children.definition: British /skeleton in your closetAmerican /ˌskelɪtən ɪn jɔːʳ ˈkʌbəʳd, ˌskelətən ɪn jɔːʳ ˈkʌbəʳd, ˌskeltən ɪn jɔːʳ ˈklɒztǁ-ˈklɑːzt/  a secret about yourself that you have kept hidden for a long time because you are ashamed or embarrassed about it:bí mật
examples: ▪ None of us is perfect -- we all have a little skeleton somewhere in the closet that we’d rather other people didn’t know about.

children.name: secret organizations and people who do secret work
secret
children.definition: /ˈsiːkrɪt, ˈsiːkrət/ bí mật
examples: secret police/agent/society etc: cảnh sát/tổ chức/cộng đồng bí mật
▪ She was kept under surveillance by the secret police for over three years.
▪ The film tells the story of a Swiss secret agent who masquerades as a grocer in order to uncover a drugs ring.
▪ a senior member of the secret service

children.name: underground
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈgraʊnd◂/ ngầm
examples: underground organization/newspaper/movement etc : Tổ chức / báo chí / phong trào ngầm vv
one that is secret and opposes the government, especially when it is too dangerous to do this publicly:
▪ Slowly, the underground resistance movement grew.
▪ Nearly 2,000 defeated fighters joined the underground Communist forces concealed in the Mekong delta.
▪ He was suspended from his job for writing an editorial in an underground paper.
go underground/be forced underground : bị buộc hoạt động ngầm
become an underground organization
▪ In 1795, the United Irish Society went underground as a revolutionary movement.

children.name: clandestine
children.definition: /klænˈdestɪn, klænˈdestən/  bí mật
examples: clandestine organization/force/operation etctổ chức / lực lượng / hoạt động Bí mật vv
one that is secret, and usually illegal:
▪ The doctor was arrested after she was named as a member of a clandestine socialist movement.
▪ His clandestine meetings with PLO officials had been secretly recorded.

children.name: undercover
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈkʌvəʳ◂/ bí mật
examples: undercover agent/police officer/investigator etc Nhân viên bí mật / sĩ quan cảnh sát / điều tra viên ngầm vv
one who works secretly for the police or government in order to catch criminals:
▪ He was arrested after trying to sell guns to an undercover FBI agent.
▪ People dived aside as undercover cops ambushed a planned post office raid.

children.name: to make sb not tell anyone about sth
swear sb to secrecy
children.definition: swear somebody to secrecy/ˌsweəʳ somebody tə ˈsiːkrəsi/  to make someone seriously promise that they will not tell anyone about something you have told them or something that they know about:
examples: ▪ ‘What’s she doing here?’ ‘I’d better not say. She swore me to secrecy.’
▪ Nobody knows much about the organization because its members are all sworn to secrecy.

children.name: between you and me
children.definition: /bɪˌtwiːn ˌjuː ən ˈmiː/  spoken used when you are telling someone that what you are saying is a secret, and you do not want them to tell anyone else about it:
examples: ▪ Between you and me, I think Elizabeth is a bit of a nightmare.

children.name: to not tell other people about a secret
not tell
children.definition: /nɒt ˈtel/  to not tell someone about something:không tiết lộ cho ai
examples: ▪ I told you not to tell anyone!
▪ ‘Who’s that letter from?’ ‘I’m not telling you.’"
not tell somebody what/how/why etc: không tiết lộ cho ai cái gì/như thế nào/tại sao
▪ Henry wouldn’t tell me what the surprise was.
▪ Penny laughed, but she wouldn’t tell me why.
not tell about: không tiết lộ về
▪ Vinny didn’t tell the police about his visit to Mahoney’s apartment.
▪ You’d better not tell Elizabeth about this
not tell of :không tiết lộ về
▪ Margaret had not yet told her sons of her planned engagement.
not tell (that) không tiết lộ rằng
▪ Carl felt I’d been deceiving him all these years by not telling him I was gay.
without telling somebody: mà không tiết lộ cho ai
▪ I was annoyed that he’d left without telling me.

children.name: keep st secret
children.definition: keep something secret/ˌkiːp something ˈsiːkrt/  to not tell other people something, because you want it to remain secret:giữ bí mật
examples: ▪ They wanted to keep their relationship secret for as long as possible.
▪ The graves were covered up in a deliberate attempt to keep the killings secret.
▪ So you’ve been keeping it secret all this time?
keep sth secret from: giữ bí mật khỏi
▪ Mary kept her illness secret, even from family members.

children.name: can keep a secret
children.definition: /kən ˌkiːp ə ˈsiːkrt/  someone who can keep a secret will not tell your secrets to other people, so you can trust them with secret information:có thể giữ kín
examples: ▪ Can you keep a secret?
▪ ‘Can I trust you?’ ‘I’m honest, and I can keep a secret’. 'Tôi có thể tin tưởng bạn không?'

children.name: keep quiet
children.definition: /kiːp ˈkwaɪət/  to deliberately not talk about something in public, especially something you are ashamed or embarrassed about:giữ im lặng
examples: ▪ Parotti had threatened to expose the illegal arrangements unless he was paid $50,000 to keep quiet.
▪ Some people disagree with what the government is doing, but they keep quiet for fear of reprisals.
keep quiet about :giữ im lặng về
▪ We used to keep quiet about some of the things that went on in the prison.
keep quiet over :giữ im lặng về
▪ I think they should have kept quiet over that.keep something quiet
keep something secret: giữ bí mật cái gì
▪ The minister denied that the case had been kept quiet or hidden
keep somebody quiet giữ im lặng ai đó
do something to stop someone telling a secret
▪ She’d been brutally murdered to keep her quiet.

children.name: keep st from
children.definition: keep something from/ˈkiːp something frɒm/  to deliberately not tell someone about something, especially because you think they would be upset if they knew the truth:không tiết lộ
examples: ▪ Edward never told anyone about his illness. He even tried to keep it from his wife. .
▪ The president has a reputation for keeping key decisions from even his closest aides.
▪ She tried in every way to keep the truth from her parents.

children.name: keep something under wraps
children.definition: /ˌkiːp something ʌndəʳ ˈræps/  to not allow people to know about something that has been officially planned or decided:giữ kín
examples: be kept under wraps Được giữ kín
▪ It’s been suggested the report was kept under wraps to avoid controversy.
▪ Ford’s new range of cars is being kept firmly under wraps until the Geneva auto show.

children.name: discretion
children.definition: /dɪˈskreʃən/  the ability to judge when you should or should not tell people things that you know about someone or something:thận trọng
examples: ▪ Absolute discretion is required from everyone working for the Royal Family.
leave something to somebody’s discretion : cho quyền lựa chọn cho ai
▪ I leave it to your discretion as to whether you should tell your colleagues
show/exercise discretion: cho thấy sự thận trọng
▪ TV commentators have shown great discretion, glossing over the problems in her personal life.
▪ Can junior managers be trusted to exercise discretion when making decisions?
be the (very) soul of discretion : là người rất thận trọng
be the sort of person who will never tell something that should be kept secret
▪ You can tell Martin anything -- he’s the very soul of discretion
discretionnoun[ U ]CAREFUL BEHAVIOUR
the ability to behave without causing embarrassment or attracting too much attention, especially by keeping information secret
_"Can you trust him with this?" "Yes, he'sthe soul ofdiscretion (= he will not tell other people) ."

children.name: secrecy
children.definition: /ˈsiːkrɪsi, ˈsiːkrəsi/  when what someone does or says is kept very secret, so that only a few people know about it:bí mật
examples: ▪ There is a great deal of secrecy within the organization.
▪ Why all the secrecy? You’ve got nothing to be ashamed of.
utmost secrecy bí mật tối đa
▪ Our commanding officer emphasized the need to maintain the utmost secrecy about the operation at all times.
swear somebody to secrecy thề ai đó để bí mật
make someone promise that they will not tell other people a secret
▪ Anna swore me to secrecy on the subject of her family until her book came out.
a veil/shroud/cloak of secrecy: dở màn bí mật/che đật bí mật/...
▪ The gunmen tracked down their target, despite the shroud of secrecy surrounding his whereabouts.

children.name: confidentiality
children.definition: /ˌkɒnfɪdenʃiˈæləti, ˌkɒnfədenʃiˈælətiǁˌkɑːn-/  the trust that exists between people who share secrets, especially between a professional person such as a doctor or lawyer and someone who gives them private advice:bí mật
examples: ▪ Alexander declined to comment, citing attorney--client confidentiality.
▪ Researchers should always be able to guarantee complete confidentiality for their subjects.
▪ Data encryption ensures the privacy and confidentiality of email messages.
breach/violate confidentialityVi phạm /vi phạm bí mật
to break confidentiality by telling someone a secret
▪ The health clinic has again been caught violating patient confidentiality.
breach of confidentiality: vi phạm bảo mật
▪ You doctor should not have told your parents about the abortion -- that was a blatant breach of confidentiality.

children.name: secretly/in secret/in secrecy
children.definition: /ˈsiːkrɪtli, ˈsiːkrətli, ɪn ˈsɪːkrt, ɪn ˈsiːkrəsi/  done without anyone else knowing:bí mật
examples: ▪ Many civilians were secretly killed and buried by soldiers
▪ My parents didn’t approve of our relationship, and we had to meet in secret.
▪ Operating in secrecy, intelligence agencies are often seen as mysterious and unaccountable for their actions.

children.name: on the quiet
children.definition: /ɒn ðə ˈkwaɪət/  if you do something on the quiet, you do it secretly, especially because you think that people will disapprove of what you are doing:làm gì đó trong bí mật
examples: ▪ His doctor has told him he mustn’t drink, but he still has the occasional brandy on the quiet.
▪ He used to flirt with the two girls, on the quiet, when his wife wasn’t looking.

children.name: behind closed doors
children.definition: /bɪˌhaɪnd kləʊzd ˈdɔːʳz/  if important official meetings, discussions, or decisions take place behind closed doors, they take place secretly without the public being allowed to see or hear them:bí mật
examples: ▪ The board members met behind closed doors to discuss the deal.
▪ Although America is a democracy, a lot of key decisions are made behind closed doors by unelected advisers

children.name: in private/privately
children.definition: /ɪn ˈpraɪvt, ˈpraɪvtli/  if you do something in private or privately, you do it where other people cannot see or hear you:cá nhân/ riêng tư
examples: ▪ Can I have a word with you in private?
▪ Although party officials give the President their public support, many are saying in private that he may have to resign.
▪ Generations of Native American children in state schools were punished for speaking their own language, even privately.

children.name: behind sb’s back
children.definition: behind somebody’s back/bɪˌhaɪnd somebodyˈs ˈbæk/  if you do something or say something unpleasant about someone behind their back, you do or say it without telling them:làm sau lưng ai
examples: ▪ I thought you were my friend. Now I find you’ve been talking about me behind my back.
▪ People laughed at him behind his back.
▪ He agrees with his boss to his face, but then criticizes him behind his back.
go behind somebody’s back: làm gì sau lưng ai
▪ I’m not happy about you going behind my back like that. You should have told me.

children.name: surreptitiously
children.definition: /ˌsʌrəpˈtɪʃəsli/  if you do something surreptitiously, you do it while other people are not looking because you do not want them to see you doing it:lén lút
examples: ▪ She glanced surreptitiously up at the clock.
▪ I found myself studying his face surreptitiously.
▪ Greenpeace claim that toxic waste has been dumped surreptitiously on west coast beaches.

children.name: furtively
children.definition: /ˈfɜːʳtɪvli/  if you do something furtively, you do it in a way which makes you look as if you are keeping something secret, especially something wrong that you have done:lén lút
examples: ▪ She looked around furtively to make sure no one was watching.
▪ The older boys hovered furtively outside the school gates, clutching thinly rolled cigarettes.

children.name: to not tell sb sth they want to know
withhold
children.definition: /wɪðˈhəʊld, wɪθ-/  to not give information, especially when you have been officially asked to do so:
examples: withhold information/evidence/facts etc
▪ Civil servants should be as helpful as possible, and withhold information only in the interests of national security.
▪ When the article was published, I asked for my name to be withheld.
withhold from
▪ He was accused of withholding vital evidence from the police.

children.name: hold out on
children.definition: /ˌhəʊld ˈaʊt ɒn/  informal to refuse to give someone the information that they want, even though they keep asking you:
examples: ▪ We all feel that members of the Medical Research Council are holding out on us.
▪ Why are you holding out on me like this? I’m your lawyer and I need to know what happened.

children.name: not give anything away
children.definition: /nɒt gɪv ˌeniθɪŋ əˈweɪ/  to not tell anyone anything about something, especially about your plans or intentions, when they are asking about them or are very interested to know about them:
examples: ▪ I asked Teresa if she thought she and Liam would get married, but she wouldn’t give anything away.
▪ Whatever the England manager’s plans are for tonight, he’s not giving anything away.

children.name: not/never let on
children.definition: /nɒt, ˌnevəʳ let ˈɒn/  to not tell someone a secret, especially when they are asking you questions about a subject connected with that secret:
examples: ▪ Don’t worry -- I won’t let on.
not/never let on about
▪ She never let on about her boyfriend’s criminal past.

children.name: behaving as if you have a secret
secretive
children.definition: /ˈsiːkrɪtɪv, ˈsiːkrətɪv, sɪˈkriːtɪv/  unwilling to let other people know what you are doing, or to give them information about yourself:bí mật
examples: ▪ Years of living alone had made her secretive and unwilling to trust anyone.
▪ Why did Stephen always have to be so secretive in his business dealings?
▪ Much of the discussion focused upon North Korea’s highly secretive nuclear program.
secretive about: bí mật về
▪ Kath’s very secretive about her past, isn’t she?

children.name: cagey
children.definition: /ˈkeɪdʒi/  informal unwilling to tell people definitely what your plans, intentions, or opinions are - use this especially when you cannot think of a good reason for someone doing this:kín đáo
examples: ▪ He gets very cagey whenever I ask him about his job.Anh ta rất láu cá mỗi khi tôi hỏi anh về công việc của anh.
cagey about : kín đáo về chuyện gì
▪ She’s very cagey about what she spends her money on, don’t you think?
play it cagey chơi bẩn
American
▪ Coach Bob Dwyer is playing it cagey over his choice of a replacement skipper.

children.name: play your cards close to your chest
children.definition: British /play your cards close to your vestAmerican /pleɪ jɔːʳ ˌkɑːʳdz kləʊs tə jɔːʳ ˈtʃest, pleɪ jɔːʳ ˌkɑːʳdz kləʊs tə jɔːʳ ˈvest/  if someone plays their cards close to their chest or vest, they do not allow other people to know what they are planning to do next:giấu diếm và thận trọng về ý định của mình
examples: ▪ Roslin, known for playing his cards close to his vest, declined to comment.

children.name: furtive
children.definition: /ˈfɜːʳtɪv/  someone who is furtive or behaves in a furtive way looks as though they are keeping something secret, especially something wrong that they have done:lén lút
examples: ▪ His movements were quick and furtive, and he spoke in a whisper.
▪ Miss Baggely appeared unconfident, almost furtive
▪ The two girls exchanged furtive glances across the dinner table and tried hard not to giggle.

children.name: secret
children.definition: /ˈsiːkrɪt, ˈsiːkrət/  doing something only in secret, so that other people do not know you are doing it:bí mật
examples: ▪ I actually think he’s probably a secret Republican voter.T
▪ He hid the fact that he was a secret drinker from his employees for many years.

children.name: closet
children.definition: /ˈklɒzɪt, ˈklɒzətǁˈklɑː-, ˈklɔː-/ ngầm
examples: closet alcoholic/homosexual/communist etc : kẻ nghiện rượu ngầm/ đồng tính ngầm/cộng sản ngầm
one who is secretly an alcoholic, homosexual etc:
▪ He finally came out in 1998, after years as a closet homosexual. Cuối cùng ông đã ra đời vào năm 1998, sau nhiều năm như một cặp vợ chồng đồng tính.
